body:
TC errors are unrelated, merging

@suneet-s Can you backport to 0.17.0?
@asdf2014 I had one comment about the error handling, it looks good otherwise
@jon-wei This was a clean cherry-pick of the original commit

This pull request has been marked as stale due to 60 days of inactivity. It will be closed in 4 weeks if no further activity occurs. If you think that's incorrect or this pull request should instead be reviewed, please simply write any comment. Even if closed, you can still revive the PR at any time or discuss it on the dev@druid.apache.org list. Thank you for your contributions.

I haven't forgotten about this branch, it has been in the back of my mind for a long time now (..like a really long time at this point heh). This PR is a really promising proof of concept, but it's still sort of rough around the edges and I think I can do even better. During this time, I've been thinking of some ideas on how this can better play into the vectorized query engine as well as how to always beat the segment sizes of the current approach. Of course I also still need to resolve the c++/java compatibility issue, because the c++ performance is too good to ignore (and also what LZ4 is doing so not without precedent in Druid) but we need a compatible java implementation in the event the native module is not able to load.

My main blocker is that I have just been waiting until I have a contiguous chunk of time to resolve these issues, which with any luck I anticipate will be in a couple of weeks over the holidays ðŸŽ„
This issue is no longer marked as stale.

- Thanks for the reply @**jp707049**, but I've been there already.

- Thanks @**himanshug**, this sounds like the start of what I'm looking for!
1) My following question would be: How do I query for all of the above metrics you mentioned, but with their "relationship" to a specific query?
Like how do I pull information (all those metrics) on a single query?
Does the queries have some type of uniqueID record that is attached to all relevant data? I tried connecting them with the "__time" value but I'm not sure its 100% accurate.

2) _GC and Page swapping activity_ - how do I do that? (an example would be appreciated!)

3) _realtime indexing_ - maybe it is set up. how do I check? and what will it provide?

1.Yeah. There are many ways to achive this such as rewriting JDK's canEncode() method  to support 
concurrent access.But,I don't think it's wise to do that because it complicates simple problem.

2.Reviewing code again,it doesn't make sense to using  CharsetEncoder enc as a member variable for it is only used in charsetFix() method and charsetFix() can not be  accessed concurrently. 

3.To some extent,I don't think it consumes less memory to using CharsetEncoder enc as a member variable than as a local variable for the former holds the CharsetEncoder enc in memory while the latter releases it when the method is finished even though it creates CharsetEncoder object much more times.

4.What is more,As an open source project, it's worth sacrificing so small memory for thread safe and good extendibility if  it does take more memory space.
I don't know if it happens in master and don't have a simple way to test that out either, unfortunately.

Hi @yongmeibian, thanks for your PR. I think the issue here is not memory consumption, but `JSONFlattenerMaker` is not designed to be thread-safe. The indexing tasks in Apache Druid are not designed to use multiple threads to process the same input data. If you want to change this architecture design, we should discuss what would be the new architecture and how we want it first.

> 4.What is more,As an open source project, it's worth sacrificing so small memory for thread safe and good extendibility if it does take more memory space.

Setting aside the discussion on memory usage for now, given that you're already maintaining a fork with presumably larger changes related to multithreaded ingestion, why do you believe that this one change is such a maintenance burden that it needs to be merged upstream?

We don't have any plans at the moment to enforce thread safety on `JSONFlattenerMaker` going forward, so there's additionally no guarantee that future changes in this area won't affect your fork.

This issue has been marked as stale due to 280 days of inactivity. It will be closed in 4 weeks if no further activity occurs. If this issue is still relevant, please simply write any comment. Even if closed, you can still revive the issue at any time or discuss it on the dev@druid.apache.org list. Thank you for your contributions.
This is still broken (we're still on 1.22) and #7218 bitrotted. This affects the new console's default task log view (rather than the old console's last 8kb link).
This issue is no longer marked as stale.

>  How do I query for all of the above metrics you mentioned, but with their "relationship" to a specific query?

all queries running in Druid are given a specific ID and that ID is propagated as a dimension in the emitted metric (typically, "id") . Please see relevant docs https://druid.apache.org/docs/latest/operations/metrics.html and try to see some of them on your cluster and it would be more clear hopefully.

> GC and Page swapping activity - how do I do that? (an example would be appreciated!)

for non-druid info , I'm afraid I would point you to just search internet for those. Typically users would send gc logs to file , some of the jvm options are described in https://druid.apache.org/docs/latest/operations/recommendations.html

> realtime indexing - maybe it is set up. how do I check? and what will it provide?

https://druid.apache.org/docs/latest/ingestion/index.html

that should hopefully get you on the right path.
This is superseded by other PRs (e.g., https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/8980)
so , "anything that changes getSerializedSize(), should be immediately followed by a  `if(getSerializedSize() > fileSizeLimit) { .. }` block" .
This pull request/issue has been closed due to lack of activity. If you think that is incorrect, or the pull request requires review, you can revive the PR at any time.
This issue has been closed due to lack of activity. If you think that is incorrect, or the issue requires additional review, you can revive the issue at any time.

Note: in IntelliJ 2019.3 it's possible to configure the "Constant conditions and expressions" inspection so that it only reports definite bugs: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-224474. We can use it in CI once it is fully upgraded: see #8080.
Labelling this issue as `Development Blocker` because it blocks #7780.

You have to `POST /druid/coordinator/v1/datasources/<datasource>` to 'enable' the datasource and force the coordinator to re-evaluate the loadRules for you.

Right now in the console the `Enable` option is only visible if the datasource is disabled, so if you do not want to use cURL you can briefly `Disable` and then `Enable` the datasource form the GUI.

The console should handle this state better.

for that post request the docs say 
 > Marks as used all segments belonging to a data source.

which doesnâ€™t match what you described above. maybe the docs need to be updated too

i tried doing a POST manually and got a 500

```
POST http://routerhost:8080/druid/coordinator/v1/datasources/kube-metrics-30m
```

i have created a separate bug #9042 for this

I wonder if we should convert [the release process guide](https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/blob/master/distribution/asf-release-process-guide.md) into a github issue template and add checkboxes next to each item in the guide. This will allow the release manager to open a 'Release Apache Druid x.y.z' issue during each release, with the template more or less as is, and go through and check checkboxes as the process is completed, with the final act of a release being the closing of the do a release issue.

Does this need to go in 0.17.0?
It can. I donâ€™t think itâ€™s a release blocker though.
@bputt , @adilev26, is there an instruction on how to setup the key/certificate of the kafka indexing service to be able to consume from Kafka via TLS?

Version mistake.
Retry after fix.

This pull request **introduces 3 alerts** when merging 15b85f6958ef2854bf8f66230b126af17aedcf94 into 6881535b48272c795be501143e9cbf9ba6290737 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/incubator-druid/rev/pr-cb27293631065ba170bcf1e855ec8bf3ec79a64f)

**new alerts:**

* 3 for Array index out of bounds

hi @Samlinxia , technically you can put any property of Kafka inside that block of config and it will pass on to the Kafka consumer as is.
I just put the following and it worked:
      "security.protocol": "SSL",
      "ssl.truststore.location": "{location of my .jks file}"
This issue has been closed due to lack of activity. If you think that is incorrect, or the issue requires additional review, you can revive the issue at any time.

Thanks again for your reply @himanshug ,
So what am I doing wrong?
the docs say: 

> 

Metric | Description | Dimensions | Normal Value
-- | -- | -- | --
query/time | Milliseconds taken to complete a query. | Common:  dataSource, type, interval, hasFilters, duration, context,  remoteAddress, id. Aggregation Queries: numMetrics, numComplexMetrics.  GroupBy: numDimensions. TopN: threshold, dimension. | < 1s

So im running two different type of query, an SQL one and a JSON one, both via the POST API.

SQL query is pretty much this:
`SELECT * FROM \"metrics\" WHERE  \"metric\" = 'query/time'`
This returns results like this:
```
{
    "__time": "2019-11-16T09:00:07.594Z",
    "count": 1,
    "dataSource": "orgrimmar",
    "hasFilters": "true",
    "host": "druid-broker1:8083",
    "interval": "2019-10-30T10:24:18.761Z/2019-11-16T09:00:01.771Z",
    "metric": "query/time",
    "numComplexMetrics": 0,
    "numDimensions": 0,
    "numMetrics": 0,
    "server": "",
    "type": "select",
    "value": 2482
  },
```
there is no "id" in that result, nor other things mentioned in the doc's (such as: duration, context,  remoteAddress...)

JSON query looks like this:
```
{
  "queryType": "select",
  "dataSource": "metrics",
  "granularity": "all",
	"dimensions": [],
	"filter": {
		"type": "in",
		"dimension": "metric",
		"values": ["query/time"]
	},
	"intervals": [
		"2019-12-16T00:00:00/2019-12-16T23:59:59"
	],
	"pagingSpec":{"pagingIdentifiers": {}, "threshold":1 }
}
```
this returns results like this:
```
[
  {
    "timestamp": "2019-12-16T00:00:00.003Z",
    "result": {
      "pagingIdentifiers": {
        "metrics_2019-12-16T00:00:00.000Z_2019-12-16T01:00:00.000Z_2019-12-16T04:35:02.747Z": 0
      },
      "dimensions": [
        "server",
        "metric",
        "hasFilters",
        "host",
        "interval",
        "type",
        "dataSource"
      ],
      "metrics": [
        "numComplexMetrics",
        "numDimensions",
        "count",
        "numMetrics",
        "value"
      ],
      "events": [
        {
          "segmentId": "metrics_2019-12-16T00:00:00.000Z_2019-12-16T01:00:00.000Z_2019-12-16T04:35:02.747Z",
          "offset": 0,
          "event": {
            "timestamp": "2019-12-16T00:00:02.010Z",
            "dataSource": "orgrimmar",
            "server": null,
            "type": "groupBy",
            "interval": [
              "2019-12-09T14:00:00.000Z/2019-12-09T15:00:00.000Z",
              "2019-12-10T13:00:00.000Z/2019-12-10T14:00:00.000Z",
              "2019-12-12T03:00:00.000Z/2019-12-12T04:00:00.000Z",
              "2019-12-12T21:00:00.000Z/2019-12-12T22:00:00.000Z",
              "2019-12-13T12:00:00.000Z/2019-12-13T13:00:00.000Z",
              "2019-12-15T02:00:00.000Z/2019-12-15T03:00:00.000Z"
            ],
            "metric": "query/time",
            "host": "druid-historical40:8083",
            "hasFilters": "false",
            "numComplexMetrics": 0,
            "numDimensions": 2,
            "count": 2,
            "numMetrics": 2,
            "value": 258
          }
        }
      ]
    }
  }
]
```
once again, there is no dimension named "id".

Am I querying this wrong, looking at it wrong, or understanding it wrong?
I have read the docs a few times now. its either I'm lacking some basic understanding of this, or I'm looking at this the wrong way.

Please advise,
thank you so much

This issue has been marked as stale due to 280 days of inactivity. It will be closed in 4 weeks if no further activity occurs. If this issue is still relevant, please simply write any comment. Even if closed, you can still revive the issue at any time or discuss it on the dev@druid.apache.org list. Thank you for your contributions.

> so , "anything that changes getSerializedSize(), should be immediately followed by a `if(getSerializedSize() > fileSizeLimit) { .. }` block" .

Or, at least that needs to be between anything that changes the serialized size and anything that depends on it being less than the fileSizeLimit. (Or less than `Integer.MAX_VALUE`)

you POST went to a service on port 8080 that is typically your broker. Unless you messed with the default ports you are posting to the wrong service and getting a 500. You need to post it to the coordinator or the router (on port 8888) which will route your request to the appropriate node

Hi @mini666, thanks for your contribution! I believe this extension would be super useful. Would you please considering splitting this PR into 2 smaller ones like one for adding support for HBase1 and another for HBase2? This PR is currently pretty big which could make review difficult.
Licenses not added to the yaml file since the dependency is a test only dependency. It's licensed under apache 2 though - https://github.com/jqno/equalsverifier/blob/master/LICENSE.md

my coordinator is indeed running on 8080.
the query above is being sent to the router node and it is forwarding it to the coordinator correctly.

monitoring proves that the coordinator is indeed receiving the query and returning 500. i just did one right now and you can see it there:



![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3190176/70946238-b0bb1080-200b-11ea-8b6a-b61e45e86c7f.png)

Please see https://druid.apache.org/docs/latest/configuration/index.html#emitting-metrics 
Druid has a emitter framework for emitting metrics . Druid does not dictate how and where emitted metrics are stored. That part of emitter framework is extensible. There are few core implementations like "logging", "http" etc .
.. and some more in extensions, see https://druid.apache.org/docs/latest/development/extensions.html#community-extensions

emitter implementation is free to remove some of the high cardinality dimensions such as id, aggregate multiple events etc if target storage system can not handle raw metrics emitted by Druid. That is what is happening in your case I think. Emitter, that your setup is using, is one of those that discards "id" dimension and probably aggregating the "query/time" into average so what you see is probably the average of two "query/time" metric events.

if you configure "logging" emitter, you should see "id" dimension in metric event in the log because "logging" emitter doesn't filter or aggregate anything but just dumps whatever it gets into the logs.

@leerho I can help look into the jdk11 compatibility issues. I've spent a fair amount of time working on dual jdk8 and jdk11 support for Druid's use of internal jdk APIs, and â€“ while a bit tedious â€“ it's not too hard once you spot the patterns. Hopefully, I'll have some time in the coming weeks.

@xvrl 
That would be great!  

I did some poking around and found that an updated Unsafe still exists in JDK11, although for how long I don't know.    I did some timing measurements and discovered that unsafe calls are noticeably slower in JDK11 than JDK8.   Possibly some redirect has been inserted.  Do you have any explanation?

It is my understanding, that the intention is that var-handles and method handles are to replace unsafe calls.   The way we use Unsafe is mostly to read-write primitives and arrays into blobs of bytes similar to what one can do with the C union / struct.   If we can replicate that with these var-handles, then we will probably be OK. 

We will also likely need to setup Multi-Release Jars (MRJARS) to accommodate both JDK8 and JDK11 code sets.  I have no experience in doing this.

Thanks again for your offer of help!!

Lee.

I forgot to say that the new inputSource and inputFormat are available since 0.17 which we are about to release.

because the middle manager and the historical have a different volume for storage, the middle manager has wrote the segment in it's own volume which is not the same as the historical one.

for local storage to work, the historical and the middle manager must have the same volume for storage.

set the following in the environment file:
```
druid_storage_type=local
druid_storage_storageDirectory=/opt/druid/var/segments
```


and change the docker-compose.yml to use the following:
```
  historical:
    image: apache/incubator-druid:0.16.1-incubating
    container_name: historical
    volumes:
      - data_node_var:/opt/druid/var
    depends_on: 
      - zookeeper
      - postgres
      - coordinator
    ports:
      - "3003:8083"
    command:
      - historical
    env_file:
      - environment

  middlemanager:
    image: apache/incubator-druid:0.16.1-incubating
    container_name: middlemanager
    volumes:
      - data_node_var:/opt/druid/var
    depends_on: 
      - zookeeper
      - postgres
      - coordinator
    ports:
      - "4001:8091"
    command:
      - middleManager
    env_file:
      - environment
```
Thanks for the fix. The changed behavior makes more sense to me.

Is this still being tracked?

I'm under the impression that folks are encouraged to use SQL as the "default" way of querying Druid these days, with native queries only as an advanced use case, and I'd like to start switching our automated usage over to SQL too when feasible.  But without this support (or a reliable way to escape strings from at least Java code), I'm not comfortable doing so for anything that needs user-controlled substitution...

One note: given that parameters are specified in a list, could it be legal to leave out *all* ordinals and have them default to their 1-based list index if they are all missing?
This issue is no longer marked as stale.

I suspect there's some missing logic in TimeBoundaryQueryRunnerFactory.  For example, I'm not an expert on the query execution code but it seems like (if you specify `filter`) it touches every segment.  Also even if you're only requesting `maxTime` or `minTime` via `bound`, it looks up both if you specify `filter`.

Would it be possible to add a unit test for this? Thanks!
